bug.short_desc: Data in virtual list jumps around (renders differently), given same input data

long_desc.thetext:
Created attachment 1252 Playground example of problem. See initial description in bug report for instructions to reproduce.
If the same data is given to a virtual list multiple times, it will display the data differently, and scrolling within the list causes the list to display differently.
I've created a playground example, attached. To reproduce the problem, run this in the playground and close the Log window. If you don't see changes in the display every two seconds, try scrolling the list down until "9ea8" becomes fully visible. You'll see that "int" (or a few instances of "int") jump between various rows.
Note that this problem happens without the 2-second timer too. By simply scrolling around, various fields in the list will sometimes jump around.
I see this behavior in both Chrome and Firefox.
Derrell

The example is too complex I could not find the reason what exactly is responsible for this flickering. I guess that the widgets which are pooled back to the pool are not reset correctly.
Could you try to reset all values (also the visibility) to the initialization value. Does this solve your issue?

(In reply to comment #1) > The example is too complex I could not find the reason what exactly is > responsible for this flickering. I guess that the widgets which are pooled back > to the pool are not reset correctly. > > Could you try to reset all values (also the visibility) to the initialization > value. Does this solve your issue?
Maybe that's my problem. I'm currently not resetting anything. When/where/how do I do so?
Thanks for looking at it!
Derrell

(In reply to comment #2) > Maybe that's my problem. I'm currently not resetting anything. When/where/how > do I do so? Just add a onPool[1] method to the delegate.
[1] http://demo.qooxdoo.org/current/apiviewer/#qx.ui.list.core.IListDelegate~onPool!method_public

(In reply to comment #1) > Could you try to reset all values (also the visibility) to the initialization > value. Does this solve your issue?
Resetting only the 'type' property, which is the field which keeps bouncing around, solves the problem. (I also had to modify the "apply" function for that property, to ignore null values so that resetType() would work.)
For my application, this fixes the problem. Thanks for leading me towards a solution! Should it be necessary, however, to manually reset property values? Shouldn't all values be reset automatically when a widget is taken from the pool and reused?
Derrell

(In reply to comment #4) > Resetting only the 'type' property, which is the field which keeps bouncing > around, solves the problem. (I also had to modify the "apply" function for that > property, to ignore null values so that resetType() would work.) > > For my application, this fixes the problem. Thanks for leading me towards a > solution! Should it be necessary, however, to manually reset property values? > Shouldn't all values be reset automatically when a widget is taken from the > pool and reused?
It's good to hear that you can solve your problem. Normally you do not need to reset a property value because the widget get the correct value applied from the data binding when it is reused. The widget is responsible to keep his state "clean".
Only states and visibility behavior has to reset manually to a default value.
I guess the main problem was that the apply function from the type property. Maybe the your changes now keeps the state "clean". What happens when you now do not reset the type property? Does this also work?

(In reply to comment #5)
> I guess the main problem was that the apply function from the type property. > Maybe the your changes now keeps the state "clean". What happens when you now > do not reset the type property? Does this also work?
Unfortunately, not. I thought of that immediately, but the reset is required to solve the problem.
It seems reasonable that when an item is taken from the pool to be reused, each of its properties should probably be reset. It could be done inside of a try/catch, so that in cases like mine where the apply function doesn't allow a reset, a log message could be produced (once!) so the developer knows to fix the apply function to allow for resetting.
I did end up having to reset other properties too. There was additional data bouncing around, in other fields, that I hadn't previously noticed. This does seem to be an issue that we should try to find a general solution to.
Derrell

(In reply to comment #6) > (In reply to comment #5) > > > I guess the main problem was that the apply function from the type property. > > Maybe the your changes now keeps the state "clean". What happens when you now > > do not reset the type property? Does this also work? > > Unfortunately, not. I thought of that immediately, but the reset is required to > solve the problem. > > It seems reasonable that when an item is taken from the pool to be reused, each > of its properties should probably be reset. It could be done inside of a > try/catch, so that in cases like mine where the apply function doesn't allow a > reset, a log message could be produced (once!) so the developer knows to fix > the apply function to allow for resetting. > > I did end up having to reset other properties too. There was additional data > bouncing around, in other fields, that I hadn't previously noticed. This does > seem to be an issue that we should try to find a general solution to. > > Derrell
I talked with Martin about the idea to reset all properties. We think this would not be possible, because the main problem is that we doen't know which property should be reseted and which not. We can't reset all properties, because properties can set on runtime, for example with the configureItem method, and these values would also reseted.

(In reply to comment #7) > I talked with Martin about the idea to reset all properties. We think this > would not be possible, because the main problem is that we doen't know which > property should be reseted and which not. We can't reset all properties, > because properties can set on runtime, for example with the configureItem > method, and these values would also reseted.
Understood. This may end up being primarily a documentation issue. At present, I don't think there's much discussion of when/why you might want or need to reset properties.
Where to put that documentation is a big question. One other possible solution, which would also provide a good place to document and discuss the issue, is to add an additional key in properties of data models: 'reset'. If the 'reset' key is true for a property, then before the delegate's onPool method is called, that property would be reset.
BTW, even with the reset, I still saw one place where the rendered value was changing every two seconds with the same data model being provided. We have still not, apparently, determined the complete solution to this problem.
Derrell

(In reply to comment #8) > Understood. This may end up being primarily a documentation issue. At present, > I don't think there's much discussion of when/why you might want or need to > reset properties. > > Where to put that documentation is a big question. One other possible solution, > which would also provide a good place to document and discuss the issue, is to > add an additional key in properties of data models: 'reset'. If the 'reset' key > is true for a property, then before the delegate's onPool method is called, > that property would be reset. > > BTW, even with the reset, I still saw one place where the rendered value was > changing every two seconds with the same data model being provided. We have > still not, apparently, determined the complete solution to this problem.
I've found the rest of the solution (for my case). The problem was that my "list item" class has a set of properties that do NOT map one-to-one to displayed fields. Instead, the property values determine what gets displayed. Resetting the properties did not necessarily clear all of the fields in the list item class. I solved this by explicitly calling, from onPool(), a clear() function which resets the values of all of the fields in the class.
I'm not sure there is a general solution to be found for this other than adding more documentation about onPool. My suggestion for the 'reset' key in the property would not have worked for this. I suspect that it's not typical, except in fairly sophisticated programs, for there not to be a one-to-one mapping between the property and the field in which that property is displayed. This took a lot of investigation to figure out what was going on, so somehow documenting it would be really good. It'd be nice if others didn't need to need to go through this pain.
Derrell
You are right we should improve the documentation for the usage. I opened a separate bug report for this: http://bugzilla.qooxdoo.org/show_bug.cgi?id=7414

attachment.desc: Playground example of problem. See initial description in bug report for instructions to reproduce.
